title: Between 1 July 2019 and 30 June 2020, will an armed group from the Philippines engage in a campaign that systematically kills 1,000 or more civilians in the Philippines?
preds: Updating for passage of time.  I cannot see this event occurring in the given timeframe.

'Armed groups include but are not limited to state security forces, rebel armies, and other militias.' Rebel armies and other militias (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_active_rebel_groups#Philippines) are mostly active but not on a wide scale. Especially with the President's initiative to grant autonomy to Mindanao and Bangsamoro (https://www.pna.gov.ph/articles/1075575)  State security is a different story altogether if civilians deaths related to the president's war against drugs are counted. (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philippine_Drug_War)

Now the UN is getting in on the act...
https://www.theguardian.com/world/2019/jul/12/un-launches-comprehensive-review-of-philippine-drug-war

While I agree with the previous comments about the odd resolution standards, the Philippines specifically has resolved positively before for Duterte's extrajudicial killings and seems likely to do so again, though I'm adjusting down slightly from uncertainty related to that https://www.gjopen.com/EWPJan2018Dec2018

https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2019/07/amnesty-probe-duterte-crimes-humanity-190707183739997.html
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-philippines-drugs/executions-rampant-in-philippine-drug-war-u-n-probe-needed-amnesty-idUSKCN1U30BF
I suppose I had better go along with the notion that under the peculiar standards of these questions, it doesn't matter how many civilian bodies are stacked up.  They don't count unless they're all done in by the PNP or the local police of Malolos or Davao or Tacloban or someplace.    Since no one agency has a monopoly on the slaughter, this is likely to resolve as  No.  Seems perverse, to put it politely.

Agree with @cdob63 comments. As others have pointed out, wording of question makes it difficult to resolve as “yes”. The reality at macro level is rather different.
https://www.theguardian.com/world/2019/jul/08/rodrigo-dutertes-drug-war-is-large-scale-murdering-enterprise-says-amnesty

https://www.reuters.com/article/us-philippines-rights-un/philippines-faces-call-for-u-n-investigation-into-war-on-drugs-killings-idUSKCN1TZ22M
There is no question that thousands of Filipino civilians are being "systematically" killed because Duterte has either encouraged or instructed people to kill them.  However, the murders are being performed by many different groups, no one of which is likely to hit 1,000.   It will come down to the scorers:  Either each separate police and military agency is a different "armed group," or together they are an "armed group" of Duterte's minions even though they wear different uniforms.   Depends, I guess, on what the Early Warning People intend to issue warnings about.  If it's systematic mass murders encouraged by an identifiable leadership group, the Philippines will hit 1,000 every couple of months; if it requires a single organization to do the killing, the Rwanda genocide wouldn't have counted.  Similar situations prevail in Nigeria and a couple of other countries.
